content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Brian Miller: Well, I was born in Kansas, in a small town called Overland Park, and I've lived here since I was a kid. My parents were both pretty hardworking—my dad had a Bachelor's degree and worked in engineering, while my mom had an Associate's degree and was a teacher. We had a pretty stable life, and I always felt lucky to have both parents around. I grew up in a tight-knit community, and even though we weren't super wealthy, we had everything we needed. I went to a good high school, got into a state university, and earned my Bachelor's in business. After college, I landed a job in marketing, and I've been working full-time ever since. I married my wife, Sarah, a few years ago—she's a nurse, and we have two kids. Life has been good, though not without its challenges. I've always leaned slightly liberal, and I consider myself an independent, closer to the Democrats. I'm a Protestant, and I've always been proud of my German heritage. I've never served in the military, and I speak only English, but I'm grateful for the opportunities this country has given me and my family.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Brian Miller: Yeah, there was definitely a crossroads. I was in my second year of college, majoring in business, and I had this internship opportunity with a local company that was pretty small but had a lot of potential. At the same time, I got an offer to work full-time at a bigger firm in another state, which would have paid more and given me more experience upfront. I was torn because the bigger firm seemed like the safer, more stable path, but the smaller company was in my hometown, and I really wanted to stay close to my family. I talked it over with my parents, and they encouraged me to take the smaller job because they believed in the community and the people there. In the end, I chose the smaller company, and it turned out to be the best decision I ever made. I learned so much, got to build something from the ground up, and eventually helped the company grow. That experience really shaped who I am today—more patient, more resilient, and more committed to community. I think that choice defined my career path and even my personal values.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Brian Miller: I think it was a conscious choice, but not in the way you might expect. I wasn't just weighing the pros and cons of two jobs—I was trying to figure out what kind of person I wanted to be. I realized that if I took the bigger job, I might be making more money, but I could also be sacrificing time with my family and the community I grew up in. I didn't want to become someone who was always chasing the next opportunity, no matter the cost. I wanted to build something meaningful, and I believed that staying in Overland Park would give me that chance. So, I made a decision based on my values, not just my ambitions. I think that's what made it feel right.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Brian Miller: Absolutely, I think my parents played a huge role in helping me through that decision. They didn't push me toward the bigger job, but they also didn't make me feel like I was making a mistake by staying. My dad, in particular, shared some stories from his own career—how he had taken a similar path early on, choosing stability over immediate growth, and how that decision ultimately led him to a more fulfilling life. My mom reminded me that family is the most important thing, and that I should never feel guilty for wanting to be present for them. I also talked to a few mentors from the local business community, and they all encouraged me to take the smaller job because they believed in the potential of the company and the people there. In the end, it wasn't just my decision—it was a combination of their support, my values, and the people around me who helped me see the right path.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Brian Miller: Yes, I'm married to Sarah, and we've been together for almost a decade. We met in college, actually—she was studying nursing, and I was in business. We got married right after I graduated, and we've been building a life together ever since. We have two kids: a daughter, Lily, who's six, and a son, Ethan, who's four. They're both pretty active, always running around the house or outside playing. Sarah works full-time as a nurse at a local hospital, and while it's a demanding job, she's passionate about it. We try to make sure our kids know the value of hard work and kindness, and we're pretty involved in their school and community activities. We also have a small family tradition of going camping every summer—it's something we all look forward to, and it's a chance for us to disconnect from the busyness of life and just be together. Sarah and I have our ups and downs, like any couple, but we're both committed to making it work, and I feel really lucky to have her.

Going through the interview questions reminded me of how much my life has been shaped by the people and values I hold dear. From my childhood in Overland Park to the crossroads I faced in college, each decision I made was influenced by the support of my family and the community I love. Choosing to stay close to home wasn't just about a job—it was about who I wanted to be and what kind of life I wanted to build. My marriage to Sarah and our kids have brought so much joy and purpose to my life, and I'm grateful for the balance we've found between work, family, and community. Reflecting on these topics made me realize how interconnected everything is: my values, my relationships, and the choices I've made along the way. It's all part of the story that makes me who I am today.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Brian Miller: My immediate family includes my parents, John and Linda Miller, and my younger sister, Emily. My dad, John, is still working as an engineer, though he's retired from his full-time job now. He's always been a big influence on me, not just with his career but with his strong work ethic and his belief in giving back to the community. My mom, Linda, is still involved in education—she volunteers at the local library and helps with after-school programs for kids. She's always been my biggest supporter, and I think that's why I ended up choosing a career that allows me to be involved in my community as well. Emily is seven years younger than me, and we've always had a close relationship. She's a teacher now, just like our mom, and she's actually the one who encouraged me to think more about how my work impacts others. We talk often, and I really admire the way she's built her own life while staying true to her values. Our family is pretty tight-knit, and even though we all have our own paths, we always make time for each other. I think that's one of the reasons I value community so much—it's something I grew up with, and it's something I want to pass on to my kids too.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Brian Miller: Absolutely, there are a few friends and colleagues who have been really important to me over the years. One person who comes to mind is Mark Thompson—he's been my best friend since high school, and we've been through a lot together. He's a few years older than me, and he ended up going into the tech industry, but he's always had this passion for community service. We started a small volunteer group a few years back, focused on helping local families in need, and it's become something we're both really proud of. Mark's always been the one to push me to think bigger, to look beyond my own life and consider how I can make a difference in the lives of others. Then there's my colleague, Rachel, who I work with at the marketing firm. She's been a huge mentor to me, especially early in my career. She's not just good at her job—she's incredibly compassionate and always encourages her team to find purpose in what they do. I think she's one of the reasons I've stayed committed to my values in the workplace. And of course, there's Sarah's best friend, Claire, who's like family to me too. She's been there for us through every major life event, from our wedding to the birth of our kids. I don't know where I'd be without the people who have stood by me throughout the years—they've all played a role in shaping who I am today.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Brian Miller: I live in a quiet, family-friendly neighborhood in Overland Park, just a few blocks from where I grew up. It's one of those places where everyone knows each other, and there's a real sense of community. Our street, Evergreen Terrace, is lined with nicely kept homes, and there are a few parks nearby where the kids can play. I really appreciate how safe and welcoming the area is—there's always someone around to help out if you need it. We have a small community center down the street that hosts events like holiday parties, movie nights, and even some local workshops. It's become a hub for people to connect, and I've gotten involved in a few of the initiatives there. I think that's one of the reasons I feel so rooted here—it's not just a place to live, it's a place where I can contribute and be part of something bigger. My kids love it here too; they have friends from all over the neighborhood, and there's always something going on, whether it's a sports game, a school event, or just a block party. It's a great reminder of why I chose to stay close to home all those years ago.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Brian Miller: I definitely feel very safe here. It's one of the things that makes Overland Park such a great place to raise a family. There's a real sense of watchfulness among the neighbors—people look out for each other, especially when it comes to the kids. I've never had any issues with crime or safety, and I think that's because of the community spirit. We have a neighborhood watch program, and even though it's not formal, there's an unspoken understanding that we all have each other's backs. I remember one time when a car broke into a garage down the street, and within minutes, half the neighborhood was out there helping the owner and calling the police. That kind of thing doesn't happen everywhere, and it's one of the reasons I'm so grateful to live here. It's not just about the safety—it's about the trust and connection we have with one another. That's something I hope my kids grow up with too.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Brian Miller: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the upside, it's a really stable place to raise kids, and I love how close-knit the community is. There's always someone to help out, whether it's fixing a fence, helping with a project, or just lending a listening ear. I think that sense of connection is something that's really rare these days. On the downside, sometimes the pace can feel a little slow, especially compared to bigger cities. I've had moments where I've thought about moving somewhere more dynamic for my career, but honestly, I don't think I'd be as happy anywhere else. There's something about the rhythm of life here that feels right—quiet mornings, family dinners, and the kind of neighbors who remember your name. I know it's not perfect, but I feel like I've built a life here that's meaningful, and I don't see myself leaving anytime soon.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood reminded me how deeply connected I am to the people and places that have shaped my life. Talking about Sarah, our kids, and my parents made me realize how much I value the stability and love that come from being part of a close-knit family. And when I described my neighborhood, it wasn't just about where I live—it was about the sense of community, the safety, and the trust that make this place feel like home. It's easy to take these things for granted, but reflecting on them made me appreciate how much they've influenced who I am and the kind of life I want to build for my family. I think that's why I've never felt the need to leave Overland Park—it's not just a place, it's a part of me.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Brian Miller: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but there's always a mix of routine and spontaneity. I usually start my week with a morning coffee with Sarah, and we try to get the kids up and out the door by 7:30. I work from 8 to 5, Monday through Friday, and I'm in the marketing department at a mid-sized company that does a lot of work with local businesses. I enjoy my job, but I also make sure to carve out time for the things that matter most—family, community, and personal growth. On weekdays, I'm usually home by 6, and we have dinner together most nights. The kids are always excited to tell us about their day, and Sarah and I try to be fully present for those moments. On the weekends, we're usually busy with activities—soccer games, church, or maybe a trip to the park. I also try to set aside some time for myself, whether it's reading, working out, or just sitting on the porch and enjoying the quiet. There are weeks when things get a little hectic, especially with school events or work deadlines, but I've learned to embrace the rhythm of it all. It's not perfect, but it's real, and I think that's what makes life here so special.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Brian Miller: I work as a marketing manager at a mid-sized company here in Overland Park called Horizon Solutions. We specialize in helping local businesses with their branding, advertising, and digital presence. I work a standard Monday through Friday schedule, from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., though I often stay a little later on busy days or work from home a couple of times a week to get ahead on projects. I've been with the company for about seven years now, and it's been a good fit for me—both professionally and personally. The company values community involvement, which aligns with my own beliefs, and I've had the chance to work on some really meaningful campaigns that support local nonprofits and schools. It's not the most glamorous job, but I find it rewarding because I get to see the impact of our work in the community. Plus, it gives me the flexibility to be there for my family, which is something I really value.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Brian Miller: Outside of work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. I try to get up early most mornings, around 6:30, to have some quiet time before the kids are up. I enjoy reading the newspaper, sipping coffee, and sometimes going for a short walk around the neighborhood. It's my way of starting the day with intention. I also try to make time for exercise—whether it's a run, a bike ride, or a gym session—three to four times a week. I've found that staying active helps me manage stress and stay focused throughout the day. On the weekends, I like to volunteer at the community center or help out with local events, which keeps me connected to the people and causes I care about. I also have a small garden in the backyard where I grow some vegetables and flowers. It's a small project, but it gives me a sense of accomplishment and a chance to slow down and appreciate the little things. These routines might seem simple, but they're important to me—they help me balance the busyness of life with moments of peace and purpose.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Brian Miller: Well, the biggest recent change has been with the kids starting school full-time. With Lily in first grade and Ethan in preschool, our mornings have gotten a bit more chaotic, to say the least. I used to be able to take my time getting ready, but now it's a race to get everyone out the door on time. I've had to adjust my morning routine a bit—sometimes I skip my walk or cut my coffee time short to make sure the kids are ready. On the flip side, I've started reading to them more in the evenings, which has been a nice way to unwind after work. It's funny how life keeps shifting, but I think these little changes are just part of the journey. I'm learning to be more flexible and present, and I think that's something both Sarah and I are growing into as parents.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Brian Miller: Lily starts her day at 7:30 a.m., and Ethan is usually up by 7:45. They both have breakfast together, and then it's a mad dash to get dressed and packed for school. Lily goes to a public school nearby, and she's in first grade now. Her day is pretty structured—morning recess, then classes, lunch, more recess, and then after-school activities. She's in a soccer club twice a week, and she also has a music class on Thursdays. Ethan is in a preschool program that runs until 3:30 p.m., and after that, he usually goes to a playgroup with some of the other kids from the neighborhood. On days when they don't have activities, we try to keep them busy with homework, reading, or just playing outside. I think the hardest part is getting them both ready in the morning, but it's also the most rewarding part of the day because I get to see them grow and learn. I love watching Lily take her first steps into the world of school, and Ethan is always so curious and full of energy. It's a different kind of routine than when I was a kid, but it's one that feels right for our family.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood reminded me how deeply connected I am to the people and places that have shaped my life. Talking about Sarah, our kids, and my parents made me realize how much I value the stability and love that come from being part of a close-knit family. And when I described my neighborhood, it wasn't just about where I live—it was about the sense of community, the safety, and the trust that make this place feel like home. It's easy to take these things for granted, but reflecting on them made me appreciate how much they've influenced who I am and the kind of life I want to build for my family. I think that's why I've never felt the need to leave Overland Park—it's not just a place, it's a part of me.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Brian Miller: In terms of my health, I'd say I've been pretty lucky. I don't have any major chronic conditions, and I've always tried to take care of myself through diet, exercise, and regular check-ups. I've been pretty active my whole life, so I don't struggle with weight or fitness the way some people do. I do have a few minor things—like occasional back pain from sitting at a desk all day, and I've had some mild allergies that flare up during pollen season. But nothing that's ever kept me from doing the things I love. I try to eat healthy, mostly lean proteins, vegetables, and whole grains, though I'll admit I have a weakness for chocolate chip cookies. I also make sure to see my doctor at least once a year for a check-up, and I've been pretty consistent with that. Sarah and I both believe in preventive care, so we're not the type to wait until something's wrong before we do something about it. Overall, I feel good, and I think it's a combination of genetics, lifestyle, and the fact that I've never been one to take life too seriously. I've had my share of stress, especially with work and raising kids, but I've always found ways to manage it—whether it's through exercise, talking to friends, or just taking a few minutes to breathe and be present.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Brian Miller: For me, staying healthy is a mix of what makes it easy and what makes it hard. On the easy side, I've always had a pretty active lifestyle, and I think that's been a big part of why I've stayed in shape. Whether it's walking the kids to school, running errands, or even just mowing the lawn, I'm always on my feet. Plus, I really enjoy cooking, so I try to keep meals balanced and nutritious. I've never been a big fan of fast food, and I think that's helped me avoid some of the pitfalls that come with a busier schedule. On the harder side, though, it's the consistency. There are days when work gets overwhelming, or the kids are extra busy with activities, and I find myself skipping my workouts or grabbing a quick bite instead of preparing something healthy. I also struggle with the temptation to stay up late watching TV or scrolling through my phone, which can throw off my sleep schedule. But honestly, I think the key is balance. I don't have to be perfect every day—just making sure I'm making choices that support my health over time. And when I do slip up, I don't beat myself up about it. I just remind myself that it's a long-term journey, and small habits add up.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Brian Miller: In the past two years, the biggest health-related event was when I had a minor surgery to remove a small growth on my knee. It wasn't anything serious—my doctor said it was benign, but it was causing some discomfort, especially after long days at work or after playing with the kids. The recovery was straightforward, just a few weeks of rest and some physical therapy. It was a bit of a wake-up call for me, though. I realized how much I take my body for granted, and it made me more committed to staying active and listening to my body when it's telling me to slow down. I also started seeing a chiropractor once a month to help with the occasional back pain I get from sitting at my desk all day. Overall, it's been a good reminder that even small changes in how I take care of myself can make a big difference in my quality of life.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Brian Miller: Honestly, the surgery and the recovery didn't really disrupt my work or my ability to care for the kids. I was lucky that the procedure was minor and that I could still manage my responsibilities, even if I had to take it a bit easier for a few weeks. I did have to adjust my schedule a little—like taking shorter walks or avoiding the more physically demanding tasks around the house—but overall, it wasn't a major setback. What it did do, though, was make me more aware of how important it is to take care of my body. I realized that even small things, like sitting for long periods or pushing through pain, can add up over time. Since then, I've been more intentional about taking breaks, stretching during the day, and making sure I'm not overexerting myself. I think that's one of the reasons I've been able to keep up with work and family life—it's not about being perfect, but about being mindful of how my choices affect my health in the long run.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Brian Miller: Over the past year, I've been feeling pretty good overall, though there have been moments of stress and reflection. Life with two young kids is never without its challenges—there are days when I feel like I'm running on empty, trying to keep up with their needs, work deadlines, and the demands of being a part of this community. But there's also a lot of joy in it. I've been really grateful for the support of my family and friends, especially during the holidays when we all come together. I think one of the things that's helped me stay grounded is the sense of purpose I feel in both my work and my community involvement. I've been working on a few projects at the company that support local schools, and it's been rewarding to see the impact we're making. On a personal level, I've been trying to be more present for my kids, which means slowing down and really listening to them, even when life feels chaotic. I've also been more intentional about my health, making sure I'm getting enough sleep, eating better, and staying active. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm on the right path. I think the past year has been a mix of growth, gratitude, and learning to embrace the little things that make life meaningful.

Going through the interview questions about my recent changes and health made me reflect on how much life has shifted in the past year, especially with the kids starting school full-time and my own minor health issues. It's amazing how quickly things change, and how much I've had to adapt—whether it's adjusting my morning routine to get the kids out the door or learning to listen to my body when it needs rest. I used to think of health as something I could take for granted, but after the surgery and recovery, I've come to see it as something I need to actively maintain. It's not about being perfect, but about making small, consistent choices that support my well-being and the life I want to build for my family. I'm grateful for the support of my wife, my friends, and my community, because they've all played a role in helping me stay grounded through the chaos. I think these experiences have made me more mindful, more patient, and more committed to living a life that's balanced and meaningful.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Brian Miller: Honestly, I haven't struggled with depression or anxiety in the way some people do, but I think it's important to acknowledge that there have been moments when I've felt overwhelmed. There were definitely times, especially in the early days of parenthood, when I felt like I was juggling too many things at once—work, family, community responsibilities—and I wondered if I was doing enough for everyone. I remember one particularly tough week when Sarah was working late, the kids were sick, and I had a big project due at work. I felt like I was constantly running but never catching up. But what helped me was talking to someone I trusted—whether it was Sarah, my dad, or even Mark from the volunteer group. They reminded me that it's okay to feel stressed, but it's also okay to ask for help. I think the key for me has been learning to recognize when I'm feeling down and not pushing through it alone. I've started making a point to take a few minutes each day to just breathe and check in with myself, and that's made a big difference. I don't think I've ever needed professional help for mental health, but I'm grateful for the support system I have and the small habits that help me stay balanced.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Brian Miller: For my family, the past year has been a mix of challenges and blessings. Sarah has been incredibly strong, especially with her nursing job being so demanding. There were times when she was working double shifts, and I had to step up more with the kids. But honestly, we've learned to lean on each other more than ever. The kids have also grown so much—Lily is starting to understand the importance of responsibility, and Ethan is full of curiosity and questions that keep us on our toes. We've had our share of late nights and early mornings, but there's a real sense of unity in how we've navigated it all. Our family traditions, like our summer camping trips and Sunday dinners, have become even more meaningful during this time. They're our way of grounding ourselves, reminding us that no matter how chaotic life gets, we have each other. I think that's what has kept us all resilient—it's not about perfection, but about showing up for one another, day after day.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Brian Miller: For me, religion has always been a quiet but steady presence in my life. I was raised Protestant, and while I don't attend church every week, I find comfort in the values that have been passed down through my family—things like kindness, hard work, and the importance of community. My parents were pretty involved in their church growing up, and I remember going to Sunday school and youth group, which taught me a lot about faith and how to treat others. I think what keeps me connected to my faith is the way it shapes the way I live—not just through rituals, but through the choices I make every day. I don't claim to have all the answers, and I know faith can be a deeply personal thing, but for me, it's been a source of strength, especially during tough times. It's not about being perfect or following rules—it's about finding meaning in life and being part of something bigger than myself. I also appreciate how my faith aligns with my values, like caring for others and being responsible for the community I'm part of. I don't think I'd be the same person without it, even if I don't always think about it in the same way I did when I was younger.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Brian Miller: To be honest, I don't use social media all that much. I've always been more of a person who prefers face-to-face interactions or even a phone call over scrolling through a feed. I do have a Facebook account, mostly to stay in touch with family and old friends from college, but I don't spend a lot of time on it. I think it's easy to get caught up in comparing your life to others' highlight reels, and I've always felt like my life is more meaningful when I'm living it, not watching it through a screen. I do follow a few local community pages and some family groups, which helps me stay connected to what's going on in Overland Park. But for the most part, I think I'm pretty content with keeping things simple. I know some people use Instagram or Twitter to share their lives with the world, but I've never felt the need to do that. I like my privacy, and I think it's important to have moments where I'm just present without distractions. That said, I do appreciate the way social media can bring people together for good causes—like the local food drive or the neighborhood clean-up events. It's just not something that's a big part of my daily routine.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Brian Miller: Honestly, I haven't relied on social media for emotional or financial support during tough times. I think I've always leaned more on the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, and the community around me. When things get overwhelming, it's the conversations over coffee with Sarah, or a call with my dad, or even just a neighbor stopping by to check in that really help. I know some people find comfort in online communities or support groups, and I respect that—it's just not something that's ever felt natural to me. I do think there's value in having those connections, but for me, it's about the face-to-face moments. That said, I have used Facebook a few times to find local resources, like when we were looking for a family-friendly event or a volunteer opportunity. It's not a big part of my life, but I can see how it might be helpful for others.

Going through the questions about my recent health and how I've been feeling over the past year made me reflect on how much life has changed, especially with the kids starting school and my own minor health issues. It's amazing how quickly things shift, and how much I've had to adapt—whether it's adjusting my morning routine to get the kids out the door or learning to listen to my body when it needs rest. I used to think of health as something I could take for granted, but after the surgery and recovery, I've come to see it as something I need to actively maintain. It's not about being perfect, but about making small, consistent choices that support my well-being and the life I want to build for my family. I'm grateful for the support of my wife, my friends, and my community, because they've all played a role in helping me stay grounded through the chaos. I think these experiences have made me more mindful, more patient, and more committed to living a life that's balanced and meaningful.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Brian Miller: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have shifted a bit—some days I feel more balanced, and other days I feel like I'm juggling too many things at once. With the kids growing up so fast and the demands of work, there are moments when I feel like I'm constantly trying to keep up. But I've also been working on my emotional coping strategies. One thing that's helped me is taking short breaks throughout the day, even if it's just a few minutes to step outside and breathe. I've also started journaling a little more, just to process my thoughts and feelings without getting overwhelmed. I find that writing things down helps me see things more clearly. Another thing that's made a difference is making time for small, meaningful moments—whether it's a quiet conversation with Sarah, a walk with the kids, or even just sitting on the porch with a cup of coffee. I think the key has been learning to accept that I can't control everything, but I can control how I respond to it. I'm not perfect at it, but I'm getting better at being present and finding peace in the little things.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Brian Miller: Last month, our biggest expenses were related to the kids' activities and school supplies. Lily's soccer club and music class, along with Ethan's preschool and playgroup, added up to a good chunk of our budget. We also had to pay for new school uniforms and backpacks for the start of the school year. Groceries are another big one—feeding two kids, Sarah, and me isn't cheap, especially when we're trying to eat healthy. Car payments and insurance are also a significant part of our monthly costs, and we've been saving up for a new roof on the house, which has been a slow process. On the positive side, we don't have a lot of debt, and we've been able to set aside some money each month for emergencies and savings. It's not always easy, but we've learned to prioritize what's most important—like making sure the kids have everything they need and that we're staying financially stable for the long term.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Brian Miller: Last month, our household spent around $4,200, which is pretty close to our usual monthly budget. We typically spend between $4,000 and $4,500 each month, depending on the season and any unexpected expenses. The majority of that goes toward the kids' needs—school fees, extracurricular activities, and supplies. Groceries are another big chunk, especially since we try to eat healthy and often have meals at home. We also have car payments, insurance, and utilities, which are pretty standard. On the savings side, we set aside about $500 each month for emergencies and long-term goals, like college funds for the kids. It's not always easy to stick to the budget, especially with the cost of living here in Overland Park, but we've learned to be pretty careful with our money. We don't have a lot of debt, and we're always looking for ways to cut back without sacrificing the things that matter most—like family time or community involvement.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Brian Miller: We own our home. It's a three-bedroom house on Evergreen Terrace, the same street I grew up on. Buying it was a big milestone for Sarah and me—it felt like a step toward building a real future for our family. The mortgage is manageable, especially since we've been paying it off steadily over the years. We didn't have a lot when we first started out, but we were lucky to have support from our parents and some smart financial planning. The house is a bit older, but it's been well-maintained, and we've made a few upgrades over the years, like adding a new kitchen backsplash and fixing up the backyard. It's not perfect, but it's ours, and that means a lot. I think owning a home has given me a sense of stability, especially with the kids growing up. It's a place where they can run around, play, and feel safe, and that's something I'm really grateful for.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Brian Miller: Over the past year, our bills have definitely fluctuated with the seasons and life events. In the winter, our heating bill went up a bit, which is normal for Kansas, but we've been careful to keep the thermostat at a reasonable temperature to keep costs down. Then, when the kids started school in the fall, we had a spike in expenses for uniforms, supplies, and extracurricular activities. We also had to budget more for car maintenance—Sarah's car needed some repairs, and I had to replace the tires on my vehicle. On the other hand, during the summer, we spent more on groceries because we were eating out more often with the kids and going to family events. We also had a few unexpected expenses, like a new roof that we finally got fixed after putting it off for a while. But overall, we've been pretty consistent with our monthly spending, and we've made a point to track everything so we can adjust as needed. It's not always easy, but knowing where our money is going helps us stay on top of things and make sure we're still saving for the future.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family and I have grown over the past year, especially in the face of challenges. It's amazing how much life can change in a short time, and how important it is to have a strong support system. My family has been my rock—Sarah's strength, the kids' growing independence, and the way we've leaned on each other through the ups and downs. I also realized how much I value the quiet, real-life connections I have with friends and neighbors, rather than relying on social media or online communities for support. It's not always easy to stay grounded, but I'm learning to find peace in the little things, like a conversation with Sarah, a walk with the kids, or even just being present in the moment. I'm grateful for the people in my life and the lessons I've learned along the way.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Brian Miller: I try to save in a few different ways, and I think it's something that's evolved over time. We have a traditional savings account that we contribute to every month, usually around $500, as I mentioned earlier. That's for emergencies and long-term goals, like the kids' college funds. But I also have this habit of setting aside a little money each week in a separate jar for small, spontaneous purchases—like a weekend trip to the park or a family meal out. It's not much, but it helps us enjoy life without feeling like we're always cutting corners. I also try to be intentional about our spending habits, like buying in bulk when we can or using coupons for groceries. I think the key for us has been consistency—making sure we save even when life gets busy. It's not always easy, but I've learned that saving isn't just about money; it's about creating a sense of security and freedom for our family. And honestly, I think that's one of the reasons I feel so grounded here in Overland Park—it's not just a place, it's a foundation for the life we're building together.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Brian Miller: In the last year, I've been saving for both big things and rainy days, though I think the balance has shifted a bit. We've been contributing to the kids' college funds more consistently, which is something we've been planning for since they were born. I know it's a long way off, but it's comforting to know we're starting early. On the other hand, we've also been more intentional about building an emergency fund, especially after the unexpected roof repair last summer. It was a wake-up call—sometimes things happen that you don't see coming, and having that financial cushion makes a huge difference. I also try to save for small, meaningful things, like family trips or special occasions, because I believe in enjoying the moments we have. It's not always about big goals; it's about creating a sense of security and freedom for our family. I think that's why I've always felt comfortable here in Overland Park—it's not just a place to live, but a foundation for the life we're building together.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Brian Miller: In my current occupation as a marketing manager at Horizon Solutions, I oversee a team that helps local businesses with their branding, advertising, and digital presence. The most important activities involve understanding the needs of our clients, developing creative strategies that align with their goals, and executing campaigns that resonate with their target audiences. I spend a lot of time analyzing data to measure the effectiveness of our campaigns, which helps us make informed decisions and adjust our strategies as needed. I also work closely with community organizations to support local causes, which is something I really value. One of the most rewarding parts of my job is seeing the impact of our work—whether it's helping a small business grow or supporting a local school through a fundraising campaign. It's not just about selling products or services; it's about building relationships and contributing to the community in a meaningful way. That's why I've always felt like this job is more than just a career—it's a way to make a difference, even in small ways, and that's something I'm really proud of.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Brian Miller: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the season or any special projects we're working on. Most weeks, I'm in the office from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., but there are times when I stay late or work from home to meet deadlines. I also make sure to take some time off during the summer, especially when the kids are out of school, so we can all enjoy a bit of a slower pace. It's not always easy balancing work and family, but I've learned to be flexible and prioritize what matters most. I think the key is knowing when to push through and when to step back, and I've been lucky to have a job that allows me to do both.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Brian Miller: No, I haven't had more than one job throughout my career. I've always focused on building a stable, full-time career in marketing, and I've been with Horizon Solutions for the past seven years. I think that's been the right path for me—not just because of the stability it provides, but because it allows me to be present for my family. I've considered taking on side projects or consulting work on the weekends, especially when I had more free time before the kids started school, but I've always found that adding more responsibilities can take away from the time I want to spend with Sarah and the kids. I've learned to be content with one job that gives me purpose, flexibility, and the ability to contribute to the community in ways that matter to me. Plus, I've always believed in the value of focusing on one thing and doing it well, rather than spreading myself too thin.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my family and I have grown over the past year, especially in the face of challenges. It's amazing how much life can change in a short time, and how important it is to have a strong support system. My family has been my rock—Sarah's strength, the kids' growing independence, and the way we've leaned on each other through the ups and downs. I also realized how much I value the quiet, real-life connections I have with friends and neighbors, rather than relying on social media or online communities for support. It's not always easy to stay grounded, but I'm learning to find peace in the little things, like a conversation with Sarah, a walk with the kids, or even just being present in the moment. I'm grateful for the people in my life and the lessons I've learned along the way.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Brian Miller: In total, our household made around $7,500 in the past month. That comes from my salary at Horizon Solutions and Sarah's nursing job. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our expenses and still save a little for the future. I think what's important is that we're both working full-time jobs we enjoy, and we're able to provide for our family without too much stress. It's not always easy balancing work and life, especially with two kids, but I feel lucky that we've been able to build a stable income over the years. I also know that our earnings are in line with what people in Overland Park typically make, and I'm grateful for the opportunities this country has given me and my family.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Brian Miller: I've been at Horizon Solutions for about seven years now, and I've really grown into the role over time. The benefits of the job are pretty standard for a mid-sized company—health insurance for me, Sarah, and the kids, which covers a lot of the medical costs we might run into. We also get paid time off, which is something I really appreciate, especially with the kids in school. I get about two weeks of vacation a year, and I try to use that time to take the family on a trip or just relax at home. We also have sick days, which is helpful when one of the kids is under the weather or when I need to take a day off for myself. One of the things I like most about the job is that they offer some flexibility—like the option to work from home a couple of days a week, which has been a lifesaver during the busier times with the kids. It's not the most glamorous job, but it's stable, and I feel like I'm making a real impact in the community through the work we do. That sense of purpose is something I really value, and it's one of the reasons I've stayed with the company for so long.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Brian Miller: My relationships at work are pretty positive overall. I have a good rapport with my manager, Karen, who's been with the company for over a decade. She's supportive, fair, and always encourages us to think creatively. I respect her a lot, and I feel like she genuinely cares about the team's success. As for my coworkers, we've built a pretty tight-knit group over the years. We're all in different roles—some in design, some in analytics, and others in client relations—but we collaborate a lot, and there's a real sense of camaraderie. We have lunch together most Fridays, and we've even started a few traditions, like a monthly trivia night or a coffee break where we share personal stories. I think what makes the workplace feel like a community is that we all share a common goal: helping local businesses thrive. It's not just about the work we do—it's about the people we do it with, and I'm really grateful for that.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Brian Miller: My work schedule is pretty predictable, though there's some flexibility built in. I usually start at 8 a.m. and finish at 5 p.m., but I often stay a little later on days when we're launching a new campaign or wrapping up a big project. The company allows me to work from home a couple of days a week, which has been a huge help, especially when the kids are sick or when I need to get some work done after a long day with them. I also have the option to adjust my hours a bit if I need to leave early for a school event or pick up the kids from an activity. That flexibility is something I really appreciate—it helps me balance work and family without feeling like I'm constantly choosing between the two. I think that's one of the reasons I've been able to stay committed to my job for so long. It's not just about the work itself, but about having the freedom to be there for the things that matter most in life.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Brian Miller: Overall, I feel pretty good about our financial situation. We're not wealthy by any means, but we're stable, and we've been able to provide for our family without too much stress. I think the key has been budgeting carefully and making sure we prioritize what's most important—like the kids' education, healthcare, and our home. I know there are people who make a lot more than we do, and there are others who struggle a lot more than we do, but I feel like we've found a balance that works for us. I also appreciate that both Sarah and I have full-time jobs we enjoy, which gives us a sense of purpose and security. It's not always easy, especially with the cost of living here in Overland Park, but I feel lucky that we've been able to build a life that's meaningful and sustainable for our family.

Going through the questions about my financial situation and work habits made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by balance and intentionality. Thinking about our monthly budget, the fluctuating bills, and the importance of saving reminded me how much I value stability—not just financially, but in every aspect of life. It's amazing how much our expenses change with the seasons and life events, but knowing where our money goes and making conscious choices about how we spend and save has given me a sense of control. I also realized how lucky I am to have a job that offers flexibility, allowing me to be present for my family while still contributing to the community. It's not always easy, but I feel grateful for the life we've built together—where we can provide for our kids, enjoy the little things, and still have a sense of security. These reflections have made me appreciate how interconnected everything is: work, family, finances, and the choices we make every day.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Brian Miller: Yes, both my mom and dad worked while I was growing up. My dad worked full-time as an engineer, and my mom was a teacher at the local middle school. They both had stable jobs that provided for our family, and I always admired how they balanced their careers with being present for us. My mom, in particular, made sure that even though she had a busy schedule, she was always there for us—whether it was helping with homework, attending school events, or just having dinner together. My dad was the same way—he was always involved in our lives, even if he was working long hours. I think that's why I grew up valuing work-life balance so much. It wasn't just about having a good job, but about making sure that the people you love are a priority. I see that same balance in my own life with Sarah and the kids, and it's something I'm really grateful for.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Brian Miller: My dad worked as an engineer for a local manufacturing company, and his most important duties involved designing and overseeing the construction of infrastructure projects—like roads, bridges, and utility systems. He was detail-oriented and had a real passion for problem-solving. I remember him coming home with blueprints and sketches, and he'd often explain what he was working on in a way that made it feel exciting, even to a kid. My mom, on the other hand, was a middle school teacher, and her most important activities revolved around creating a safe, engaging learning environment for her students. She was always coming up with creative lesson plans and making sure each child felt seen and supported. I remember her staying late after school to help students who were struggling, and she had a way of making even the toughest subjects feel approachable. Both of them had demanding jobs, but they always made time for our family, and I think that's why I grew up with such a strong sense of what it means to work hard while still being present for the people you love.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Brian Miller: My dad worked for a company called Midland Infrastructure, which was a mid-sized firm that specialized in civil engineering projects. They did a lot of work with local governments, designing and building roads, water systems, and even some public buildings. It was a pretty traditional business, but they had a strong reputation for quality work. My mom worked at a public school district in our town, specifically at Overland Park Middle School. She taught math and science, and she was known for being patient and creative with her lessons. She made learning fun, even when the material was tough. Both of them were part of the kind of stable, community-oriented jobs that I think shaped my own values. I remember seeing my dad come home with blueprints and my mom with lesson plans, and it always felt like they were doing something important—not just for their own careers, but for the people around them. That's something I've carried with me in my own work, whether it's marketing or volunteering. It's about making a difference, even in small ways.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Brian Miller: Looking a few years ahead, I hope my life continues to be rooted in the same values that have guided me so far—family, community, and purpose. I'd love for Sarah and me to still be building a life together, with the kids growing into their own identities while still feeling the support of our family. I hope they find their own paths, whether that's staying close to home or exploring the world, but I hope they carry with them the same sense of kindness and responsibility that we've tried to instill in them. Professionally, I'd like to see my work at Horizon Solutions continue to make a positive impact, maybe even take on more leadership roles or mentor younger employees who are just starting out. I also hope to stay involved in the community, whether through the volunteer group with Mark or other local initiatives. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I hope it's filled with the same sense of connection, growth, and gratitude that I feel today. After all, life isn't about having everything perfect—it's about finding meaning in the moments that matter most.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Brian Miller: What I value the most in my life is the sense of connection—whether it's with my family, my friends, or the people in my community. I think it's easy to get caught up in the hustle of daily life, but what keeps me grounded is knowing that I have people who care about me and that I can care about them in return. I value the little moments—the conversations over breakfast, the laughter with the kids, the way the neighborhood comes together during tough times. I also value purpose, whether it's through my work, my volunteer efforts, or just being there for someone who needs support. I think life is too short to be focused only on personal success or material things. What matters most is the relationships we build, the impact we have on others, and the way we choose to live with intention and gratitude. That's what I hope my kids grow up to understand, and it's what I try to live by every day.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my work and financial situation shape the life I've built for my family. Thinking about my monthly income, the stability of my job at Horizon Solutions, and the benefits that come with it reminded me how lucky I am to have a career that supports both my family and my values. It's not about making a lot of money—it's about having enough to provide for what matters most: our home, our kids' education, and the ability to be present for the people I love. I also realized how important it is to have a workplace that values balance, like the flexibility to work from home or adjust my hours when needed. It's those little things that make the daily grind more manageable and allow me to be the kind of father, husband, and community member I want to be. I'm grateful for the stability we've found, and I hope it continues to be a foundation for the future we're building together.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a meaningful journey of reflection, reminding me of how deeply interconnected my experiences, values, and relationships are. From my childhood in Overland Park to the crossroads I faced in college, each decision I made was influenced by the support of my family and the community I love. My career in marketing, my marriage to Sarah, our two children, and the life we've built together in this tight-knit neighborhood all contribute to who I am today. I've come to realize that my sense of purpose comes not just from my work or my achievements, but from the people I care about and the values I hold dear—like kindness, responsibility, and community. I'm grateful for the stability, the challenges, and the growth that have shaped my life, and I hope to continue living with intention, gratitude, and connection as I move forward.
